Lane Rawlins]] |vice-president = |superintendent = |provost = Warren Burggren |vice_chancellor = |principal = |dean = |director = |head_label = |head = |faculty = |staff = |students = 36,067{{cite web |url=https://factbook.unt.edu/c8_fb/cgi-bin/cognos.cgi|title=University of North Texas - Enrollment Fall 2010|accessdate = 2011-06-24 |publisher=University of North Texas}} |undergrad = 28,283 |postgrad = 7,784 |divinity = |residents = 5,633{{cite web |url=http://www.unt.edu/pais/insert/uohou.htm|title=UNT - Off-Campus Housing|accessdate = 2007-07-02 |publisher=University of North Texas}} |other = |profess = |alumni = 175,000{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} |city = [[Denton, Texas|Denton]] |state = [[Texas]] |province = |country = [[United States]] |address = [[1155 Union Circle, Denton, Texas 76201]] |coordinates = |campus = [[Suburb]]an 860 acres (3.3 kmÂ²) |former_names = Texas Normal College and Teacher Training Institute (1890-1894)
North Texas Normal College (1894-1901)
North Texas State Normal College (1901-1923)
North Texas State Teachers College (1923-1949)
North Texas State College (1949-1961)
North Texas State University (1961-1989) |free_label = |free = |sports = [[NCAA]] Division I-FBS |colors = [[Green]] {{Color box|#059033}} and [[White]] {{Color box|#FFFFFF}}{{cite web |http://www.unt.edu/identityguide/web-electronic.htm|title=Indentity Guide|accessdate = 2011-09-12|publisher=University of North Texas}} |colours = |nickname = Mean Green |mascot = Scrappy |fightsong = ''[[UNT Fight Song]]'' |athletics = [[North Texas Mean Green]] |affiliations = [[Sun Belt Conference]] |publictransit = [[Denton County Transit Authority]] |nobel_laureates = |website = [http://www.unt.edu www.unt.edu] |logo = |footnotes = }} The '''University of North Texas''' ('''UNT''') is a public institution of higher education and research in [[Denton, Texas|Denton]]. Founded in 1890, UNT is part of the [[University of North Texas System]]. As of the fall of 2010, the University of North Texas, Denton campus, had a certified enrollment of 36,067.[http://www.txhighereddata.org ''Certified Comparison of Enrollments of Fall 2009 and Fall 2010,'' Texas Higher Education Data] Of the 77 senior colleges and universities in the state (38 public and 39 independent), the enrollment at University of North Texas Denton campus is [[List of largest Texas universities by enrollment|fourth largest]], behind [[The University of Texas at Austin]], [[Texas A&M University]], and the [[University of Houston]]. == Organizational structure == The university is composed of nine colleges, three schools, and one academy:
# College of Arts and Sciences # College of Business # College of Education # College of Engineering # College of Information # [[University of North Texas College of Music|College of Music]] # College of Public Affairs and Community Service # College of Visual Arts and Design # Honors College # Frank W. and Sue Mayborn School of Journalism # School of Merchandising and Hospitality Management # Toulouse Graduate School # [[Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science]] (TAMS)
== Academic highlights == Since the 1980s, North Texas has expanded its research in science and engineering. In 2006, the [[National Science Foundation]] ranked UNT Denton campus 122nd among 417 academic institutions for number of science and engineering doctorates awarded.[http://www.nsf.gov/statistics/nsf09311/pdf/tab12.pdf National Science Foundation/Division of Science Resources Statistics, Survey of Earned Doctorates, 2006] '''Research in the social sciences, humanities, professional fields, and other disciplines''' Based on the number of non-science and engineering PhDs awarded at 2,722 national institutions of higher learning in the country, North Texas was ranked: * Top 50 for awarding 3,382 non-science and engineering PhDs from 1920 to 1999 * Top 50 for awarding 551 non-science and engineering PhDs from 1995 to 1999 * Top 50 for awarding 1,695 non-science and engineering PhDs to people who also earned their baccalaureate from the same Institution.[http://www.nsf.gov/statistics/nsf06319/pdf/nsf06319.pdf Lori Thurgood, Mary J. Golladay, and Susan T. Hill, ''US Doctorates in the 20th Century: Special Report],'' [[National Science Foundation]], June 2006 Of the 37 post-baccalaureate institutions in Texas surveyed by the [[National Science Foundation]], UNT ranked third in 2006, behind [[University of Texas at Austin|The University of Texas at Austin]] and [[Texas A&M University]], for non science and engineering doctorates awarded. The [[Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching]] classifies the University of North Texas as a "Research University" with "high research activity."[http://www.carnegiefoundation.org/classifications/sub.asp?key=748&subkey=16383&start=782 ''Classifications'', [[The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching]], 2004]. '''Visual Arts & Design''' UNT's '''College of Visual Arts and Design''' — one of the eleven colleges and schools on the [[Denton, TX|Denton]] campus — has the 10th largest enrollment of any art and design school accredited by the [[National Association of Schools of Art and Design]], and has the second largest of any that awards doctorates.''HEADS Data – Special Report, 2010-11'', [[National Association of Schools of Art and Design]] {| class="references-small" border="0" cellpadding="0" style="border:1px solid #A3B1BF; color: black; background-color: white;" |-valign="bottom" style="text-align:center" |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:Beige"| |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:Beige"|College of
Visual Art
Design |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:Beige"|Size
Rank |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:Beige"|Size
Rank with
Doctorates |-valign="bottom" style="text-align:center" |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2006-07 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2443 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|7 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|1 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2007-08 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2206 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|10 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2008-09 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2265 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|10 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2009-10 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2290 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|10 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2010-11 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2324 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|10 |width="33.33%"; style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2 |} '''College of Music''' The '''[[University of North Texas College of Music]]''', organized by discipline in eight academic divisions, is a comprehensive music school with the largest enrollment of any music institution accredited by the [[National Association of Schools of Music]],''HEADS Data – Special Report, 2010-11'', [[National Association of Schools of Music]] and the first in the world offering a degree in [[Timeline of jazz education|jazz studies]]. The College of Music has been among the largest music institutions of higher learning in North America since the 1940s. North Texas has been a member of the [[National Association of Schools of Music]] for {{age|1939|01|01}} years.[http://books.google.com/books?id=uEqJXwQHe6kC&pg=PA21&lpg=PA21&dq=%22E.+J.+McKissack%22&source=bl&ots=t0bKZOY53i&sig=J-Bdtf692Ngjha5ESlpGmN0OSq8&hl=en&ei=FMYJSpOVKJOwMaWNzNsL&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4#v=onepage&q=music&f=false James Lloyd Rogers (1926-2006), ''The Story of North Texas'', University of North Texas Press] (c2002) For at least four decades, approximately one-third of all North Texas music students have been enrolled at the graduate level. '''Affiliations''' A member of the [[Federation of North Texas Area Universities]], North Texas offers various graduate degrees in coordination with nearby [[Texas Woman's University]] and [[Texas A&M University-Commerce]]. The university is accredited by the [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]]. '''Intercollegiate athletics''' UNT's athletics programs, nicknamed the [[North Texas Mean Green|Mean Green]], compete in thirteen [[NCAA Division I-A]] sports and have been members of the [[Sun Belt Conference]] since 2001. ==History== [[File:Murchison 1.jpg|thumb|right|Winspear Auditorium, [[University of North Texas College of Music]] (photo by Craig D. Blackmon, FAIA, courtesy of Holzman Moss Architecture)]] The university was founded in 1890 by Joshua Crittenden Chilton as the '''Texas Normal College and Teachers' Training Institute''' and was originally housed in leased facilities above a hardware store. In 1893, overworked and facing poor health, Chilton turned the school over to John Jackson Crumley. Renamed '''North Texas Normal College''', the school was once again turned over to Menter B. Terrill in 1894. By 1899 the school had been made a state institution by the Texas Legislature, becoming '''North Texas State Normal College''' under its fourth president, J.S. Kendall. In 1923, after president William H. Bruce's suggestion, the school underwent its fourth name change, becoming '''North Texas State Teachers' College'''. Under president Dr. W. Joseph McConnell, the college grew tremendously; the first master's degrees were awarded in 1936 and the school was given its own Board of Regents in 1949, changing its name once again to '''North Texas State College'''. President Dr. J.C. Matthews' tenure also saw important development. In 1961 the college became '''North Texas State University''', and by 1964 was approved by the Texas Commission on Higher Education to begin several doctoral programs. In 1988, the university changed names one final time, becoming the '''University of North Texas'''.[http://www.unt.edu/traditions/ University of North Texas] ==Academics== {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2011}} {{Main|University of North Texas academics}} {{Infobox US university ranking | Forbes = 241 | USNWR_NU = 203â268 }} The University contains 12 colleges and schools and offers 97 bachelors, 101 masters and 48 doctoral degree programs. The student-faculty ratio at UNT is 23:1, and 28.8 percent of its classes consist of fewer than 20 students. The most popular majors include Business, Management, Marketing, Communication, Journalism, English, Multi/Interdisciplinary Studies, and Visual and Performing Arts.U.S. News & World Report [http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/unt-3594]. The University ranks in the [[U.S. News & World Report]]'s top 100 programs in Clinical Psychology (99), Fine Arts (58), Library and Information Studies (17), Health Librarianship (3), School Library Media (11), Service for Children and Youth (13), Physician Assistants (38), Public Affairs (57), City Management and Urban Policy (9), and Rehabilitation Counseling (13).U.S. News & World Report UNT is well known for its [[University of North Texas College of Music|College of Music]]. The college was founded in 1890 as the Normal Conservatory of Music and is now recognized as one of the top five music schools in the country. Several of the university's colleges were founded in the last ten years, including the College of Information, the College of Engineering, and the Mayborn School of Journalism. UNT is also home to the [[Texas Academy of Mathematics and Science]], a two-year residential early college entrance program, and the [[Turkish Institute for Police Studies]]. Other University rankings and ratings include: * Ranked 12th in a list of the Top 25 "Best Buys" for an online MBA by GetEducated.com[http://www.geteducated.com/online-college-ratings-and-rankings/best-buy-lists/best-buy-online-masters-mba-aacsb ''Best Online MBA Rankings AACSB - Top Affordable Distance MBA'', Elizabeth Elizabeth Phillips (born 1963), editor], Get Educated, Inc. (Vermont) * In the 2010 edition of US News & World Report's ''Americaâs Best Graduate Schools'' * The College of Education graduate programs are ranked 109th out of 278 institutions. It is placed 89th among the 100 public universities. * The Department of Family Medicine is ranked 17th in the country. * The [[University of North Texas Health Science Center|Texas College of Osteopathic Medicine]] ([[University of North Texas Health Science Center|TCOM]]) at the [[University of North Texas Health Science Center]] is placed in the Top 50, rated 20th in primary care among medical schools and 34th for the Physician Assistant program. [[File:unttower.jpg|thumb|left|Hurley Administration Building]] ==Campus== ===Residence halls=== [[File:University of North Texas - Mozart Square.JPG|thumb|Mozart Square]] Students who live on campus at UNT have a variety of housing options. There are 13 halls and each hall offers different amenities and communities. All dorms have wired and wireless internet access available and are staffed by resident assistants.[http://reslife.unt.edu/housing/reshalls.php UNT Housing - Residence Halls] *'''Bruce Hall''' *'''Clark Hall''' *'''College Inn''' *'''Crumley Hall''' *'''Honors Hall''' *'''Kerr Hall''' *'''Legends Hall''' *'''Maple Hall''' *'''McConnell Hall''' *'''Mozart Square''' *'''Santa Fe Square''' *'''Traditions Hall''' *'''Victory Hall''' *'''West Hall''' ===Real Communities=== UNTâs Residence Life also offers the REAL Communities program, short for Residents Engaged in Academic Living. The REAL communities offer students the ability to live with other residents in their major, and allow them to interact with each other and participate in programs that are geared towards their major or discipline.[http://reslife.unt.edu/housing/real.php UNT Housing - REAL] *'''Jazz Studies''' â Bruce Hall *'''Art & Design''' â Kerr Hall *'''RTVF''' (Radio Television and Film) - Kerr Hall *'''Health & Wellness''' â Maple Hall *'''Health Professionals''' â Clark Hall *'''UNT Serves''' â Kerr Hall *'''Global Learning'''â Kerr Hall *'''Emerald Eagle Scholars Community''' â Maple Hall *'''Transfer Student Community''' â Traditions Hall *'''Journalism''' â Kerr Hall *'''Business''' â Kerr Hall *'''School of Merchandising and Hospitality Management''' â Kerr Hall *'''Exploring Majors'''- Kerr Hall *'''Engineering''' - Kerr Hall ==Student life== [[File:The Willis Library.jpg|thumb|The Willis Library]] ===Greek life=== The UNT Greek community is made up of four councils and 39 fraternities and sororities.[http://greeklife.unt.edu/about_us/index.html UNT Greek Life About Us] 5% of male students join fraternities and 4% of female students join sororities.[http://collegesearch.collegeboard.com/search/CollegeDetail.jsp?collegeId=3551&profileId=8 The College Board's information on Housing and Campus Life] ===Traditions and symbols=== ====Mascot==== UNT's mascot is the [[eagle]] and was adopted in 1922 in a student election over the dragon, the lion, and the cottontail rabbit."UNT InHouse" (faculty newsletter), December 22, 2005 (retrieved September 17, 2007) [http://inhouse.unt.edu/index.cfm?date=12/2005 Unt.edu] This selection is said to have reflected the student population's ideals of individual liberty and freedom of expression, values the UNT community continues to cherish.{{Clarify|date=June 2011}} The costumed eagle character, Scrappy, appears at sporting and university events, though he didn't always go by that name; in 1974, students who felt "Scrappy" was too warlike dubbed the bird "Eppy," and he kept that name until 1995. Athletic teams are referred to as the "Mean Green." This name is usually associated with football star and 1969 graduate [[Joe Greene (American football)|"Mean" Joe Greene]], a legendary member of the famous [[Steel Curtain]] defense of the 1970s [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]; however, accounts vary about the actual origins of "Mean Green."[http://www.unt.edu/northtexan/archives/w04/mean.htm University of North Texas North Texan Online Fall 2004: Mean Green video memories] In the spring of 2002, the school's chapter of the Albino Squirrel Preservation Society attempted to make the group's namesake the school's secondary mascot. The student body narrowly rejected the measure.North Texas Daily, April 8, 2003 (retrieved September 17, 2007) [http://media.www.ntdaily.com/media/storage/paper877/news/2003/04/08/UndefinedSection/Students.Express.Opinions.In.Sga.Vote-1887675.shtml NTdaily.com]{{Citation broken|date=June 2011}} In August 2006, the albino squirrel, believed to bring luck to students who spotted him before an exam, was killed by a red-tailed hawk.North Texas News Service, February 2006 (retrieved September 17, 2007) [http://www.unt.edu/northtexan/archives/f06/untnews.htm Unt.edu] By May 2007, another albino squirrel had been born on campus.Albino Squirrel Preservation Society Web site (retrieved September 17, 2007) [http://orgs.unt.edu/asps Unt.edu] ====UNT Fight Song==== After winning a university sponsored contest, alumnus Francis Stroup wrote the school's fight song in 1939. Throughout the years, the song has changed its lyrics to reflect the name changes of the university. ''Let's give a cheer for U of NT;''
''Cheer for the Green and White.''
''Victory's in store whatever the score,''
''Our team will ever fight! Fight! Fight! Fight!''
''Shoulder to shoulder we march along,''
''Striving for victory.''
''Playing the game for the honor and fame,''
''And the glory of UNT.''
''U ... N ... T ... Eagles!''
''UNT Eagles Fight, Fight, Fight!'' ====Alma Mater==== In 1919, [[Julia Smith (composer)|Julia Smith]], member of the university's band (now called the [[Green Brigade Marching Band|Green Brigade]]), composed '''"Glory to the Green and White"''' which was adopted as the school's [[alma mater]] in 1922. ''Singing glory to the green,''
''Singing glory to the white,''
''For we know our university is''
''striving for the right,''
''Down the corridor of years,''
''We'll forget the joys and tears,''
''But North Texas, North Texas,''
''We love!'''' ====Traditions==== [[Image:UNT Eagle statue.jpg|right|thumb|"In High Places" is a prominent representation of the eagle on campus.]] * The '''Spirit Bell''' is a 2,000-pound bell originally brought in from Michigan in 1891 to signal class changes and curfew. Members of the Talons spirit group later began running it up and down the field at football games; it was retired to the University Union in 1982 after it developed a crack. A 1,600-pound Spirit Bell is currently in use at games. * '''McConnell Tower''', the clock tower atop the Hurley Administration Building at the center of campus, is bathed in green light for each victory by a UNT athletic team. It appears on the official class ring with two different times on its faces: 1:00 (for the One O'Clock Lab Band) and 7:00 (the 1892 curfew time for Texas Normal College and Teacher Training Institute students). * The '''eagle talon''' hand gesture is made by curling the thumb, index and middle fingers forward, leaving the ring finger and pinky closed against the palm. * A bonfire is built with thousands of pallets donated by [[Miller Brewing]] of Denton and the local [[Peterbilt]] plant. The pallets are stacked in a 40-foot by 40-foot footprint then stacked to a final height of 25 feet. It is assembled by members of the Talons spirit group the week before Homecoming and is lit on the Friday night of Homecoming week (when a burn ban is not in effect). * [http://incipientstage.20megsfree.com/images/boomerlimberfouts1_792x594.jpg'''Boomer the Cannon'''], hand crafted from solid oak on the Denton campus, the 7/8th scale M1841 6 pound, smooth bore muzzleloader cannon has been used to signify scores by the Mean Green since Fall 1970. Since that time "Boomer the Cannon" has gone through three different phases of restoration by Talon alumni. The final was in the Fall of 2007 in which the final phase saw him fitted with a custom Limber to assist with transportation and equipment handling. * The '''Green Machine''' is a green 1931 Ford Model A Tudor Sedan and is driven by members of the Talons Cannon Crew at home football games and special events. This should not be confused with the ''Mean Green Machine,'' a large mechanical eagle trailed by remote panel in a truck, controlled by three physics students, that made Homecoming and other appearances between 1968 and 1976. The Green Machine is currently undergoing an overhaul by members of Talons Cannon Crew. * '''"In High Places"''', a 22-foot-tall bronze statue of a flying eagle created by Gerald Balciar, is a popular landmark and meeting place, and is often decorated in green for school spirit. It was dedicated during the university's centennial celebrations in 1990. ===Media=== * [[KNTU]] (88.1 FM) is a university-owned student-run campus [[radio station]] which plays primarily jazz.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} * The ''[[North Texas Daily]]'' is a student newspaper published Tuesday-Friday during the fall and spring semesters and weekly during the summer.[http://www.ntdaily.com/ NTDaily] * [http://www.ntr.unt.edu/ ''North Texas Review''] is the UNT student-submitted, student-run literary journal.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} * [[NTTV]], UNT's 24-hour [[cable television]] station featuring student-produced and student-centered programming.[http://nttv.unt.edu/ North Texas Television | We Are North Texas] * The ''Aerie'', student yearbook{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} ==Athletics== {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2011}} {{Main| North Texas Mean Green}} [[Image:Mean Green Eagle Double Stacked.png|right|thumbnail|UNT's Athletic Teams are commonly referred to as the ''Mean Green'']] UNT competes at the Division I level and has been a member of the [[Sun Belt Conference]] since 2001. In the SBC, Arkansas State, Troy, and Middle Tennessee are rivals for UNT. The school competes in the following varsity sports: [[Basketball]], [[Cross country running|Cross Country]], [[Diving]], [[American football|Football]], [[Golf]], [[Football (soccer)|Soccer]], [[Softball]], [[swimming (sport)|Swimming]], [[Tennis]], [[Track and field|Track and Field]] and [[Volleyball]]. Additionally, UNT offers numerous athletic sports clubs, including the following:[http://www.unt.edu/recsports/sportclubs/clubs.html] [[aikido]], [[baseball]], [[Pocket billiards|billiards]], [[bowling]], [[cycling]], [[fencing]], [[ice hockey]], [[inline hockey]], men's & women's [[lacrosse]], [[racquetball]], men's [[rugby union|rugby]], men's [[Football (soccer)|soccer]], [[tennis]], [[triathlon]], men's & women's [[Ultimate (sport)|ultimate disc]], [[wakeboarding]]. === Football === {{Main| North Texas Mean Green football}} [[File:Stadium web.jpg|thumb|225px|A rendering of the completed [[Mean Green Stadium]]]] Founded in 1913, the Mean Green football team has won 24 conference championships, with the last four coming most recently in 2001-2004 in the [[Sun Belt Conference]].{{cite web|url=http://cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/sunbelt/north_texas/championships.php|title=North Texas Championships|publisher=College Football Data Warehouse|accessdate=2007-08-20}} The team has appeared in a total of 7 [[bowl games]], winning 2, most recently the [[New Orleans Bowl]] in 2002. [[Dan McCarney]] is the current head coach. From 1952 to 2010, home football games were played at [[Fouts Field]]. In October 2008, students approved a new dedicated athletics fee to fund the construction of a new football stadium. The vote passed 2,829 (58%) YES to 2,038 (42%) NO. UNT played its first game in [[Apogee Stadium]] on September 10, 2011, losing 23-48 to the University of Houston.{{cite web|http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=312530249|title=Houston Cougars vs. North Texas Mean Green|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=9/12/11}} === Men's basketball === {{Unreferenced section|date=March 2011}} {{Main| North Texas Mean Green men's basketball}} North Texas has recently experienced success under head coach [[Johnny Jones (coach)|Johnny Jones]]. During the 2006-2007 season, North Texas won its first ever Sun Belt Conference title and advanced for the first time since 1988 to the NCAA Tournament. Only three of the state's 20 Division I teams had more wins than North Texasâ 23 in 2006-07. The 2006-07 effort was the beginning of a four year stretch of 20+ win seasons. North Texas won the Sun Belt Conference title a second time during the 2009-10 season to advance to the NCAA Tournament for the second time in four years. Since 1973, the team has played its home games in the [[UNT Coliseum]]. == Notable alumni and professors == {{Main|Notable University of North Texas Alumni}} Today, the University of North Texas has 175,000 living alumni; 100,000 residing in the [[DallasâFort Worth Metroplex]].{{cite web |url=http://www.unt.edu/northtexan/archives/s05/branding.htm|title=North Texan Online 2005|accessdate = 2007-07-05 |publisher=University of North Texas}} A significant number of notable alumni have succeeded in music, including [[Roy Orbison]], [[Meat Loaf]], [[Tom Malone (musician)|Tom "Bones" Malone]] and [[Lou Marini|"Blue Lou" Marini]] (both members of [[The Blues Brothers]] Band and the [[Saturday Night Live Band]]), [[Lecrae Moore]] ('02) Reach Records, [[Grammy Award]]-winners [[Don Henley]], [[Norah Jones]] and [[Pat Boone]]. KDGE disc jockey Josh Venable attended the radio school here.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} Notable former North Texas athletes include [[American Football League]] MVP [[Abner Haynes]], [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] member [[Joe Greene (American football)|"Mean" Joe Greene]], and [[PGA Championship|PGA champion]] [[Don January]]. Professional wrestlers [[Stone Cold Steve Austin]], [[David Von Erich|David]] and [[Kevin Von Erich]] are also alums of North Texas athletics, under the names of Steve Williams (football), David Adkisson (basketball) and Kevin Adkisson (football) respectively.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} North Texas political alumni include [[Michael C. Burgess]], current congressman for the [[United States House of Representatives, Texas District 26|26th Texas district]]; [[Adel al-Jubeir]], Saudi ambassador to the United States and former adviser to the Royal Court of Saudi Arabia; former congressman [[Ray Roberts]] of the [[United States House of Representatives, Texas District 4]] (and namesake of nearby [[Lake Ray Roberts]]); and [[Charlie Fern]], former [[White House]] [[speechwriter]] for [[First Lady]] [[Laura Bush]], who worked as a reporter and editor on UNT's newspaper, the ''[[North Texas Daily]]''.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} Notable professors include former House of Representatives Majority Leader [[Dick Armey]] and [[wind symphony]] conductor [[Eugene Corporon]], who is considered an authority on wind/band music repertoire.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} Other significant alumni include journalist and author [[Bill Moyers]], former 1971 [[Miss America]] [[Phyllis George]], [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning author [[Larry McMurtry]], [[Phil McGraw]] ('79) from the American television show [[Dr. Phil (TV series)|Dr. Phil]] and [[Mark L. Pierson]] ('90) Chief of Staff at [[Hewlett-Packard]] Software and Solutions, [[International Lutheran Fellowship]] Archbishop Robert Hotes with [[Benedictine University]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} Eli Young Band == North Texas firsts == {{Refimprove section|date=May 2011}} Since its founding the university has introduced several different programs and models into the American postsecondary system:{{cite web |url=http://www.unt.edu/majors-catalogs.htm |title = UNT first|accessdate = 2010-05-16 |publisher=University of North Texas}} *First in the U.S. to offer programs in aging studies, [[jazz]] studies, emergency administration and planning, oil and petroleum accounting, and business computer information systems *First bachelor's degree in electronic merchandising in the U.S. *First accredited counseling program in the U.S., which still ranks among the nation's best. *First school in the country to offer a degree in Mechanical and Energy Engineering. *First fully online master's program in [http://anthropology.unt.edu/grad-online.php applied anthropology]. *First environmental ethics program in the country to offer the Ph.D., which is considered the best in the nation *First PhD program in art education in the U.S. *First patent for silicon-based ultra-sensitive chemical sensor for use in integrated circuit fabrication. *First online school library preparation program in the U.S. *First college in the South to [[Desegregation|integrate]] African Americans (1952) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} Eli Young Band ==External links== {{Commons category|University of North Texas}} * [http://www.unt.edu/ University of North Texas] * [http://www.meangreensports.com/ North Texas Athletics] * [http://www.ntdaily.com/ ''North
